column2: _In Which the Reader Is Again Introduced to Captain Armine, during His Visit to London_.

column2: MISS GRANDISON had resolved upon taking a house in London for the season, and had obtained a promise from her uncle and aunt to be her guests.
column3: MISS GRANDISON had resolved upon taking a house in London for the season, and had obtained a promise from her uncle and aunt to be her guests.

column2: Lady Armine's sister was to join them from Bath.
column3: Lady Armine's sister was to join them from Bath.

column2: As for Ferdinand, the spring had gradually restored him to health, but not to his former frame of mind.
column3: As for Ferdinand, the spring had gradually restored him to health, but not to his former frame of mind.

column2: He remained moody and indolent, incapable of exertion, and a prey to the darkest humours; circumstances, however, occurred which rendered some energy on his part absolutely necessary. His creditors grew importunate, and the arrangement of his affairs or departure from his native land was an alternative now inevitable.
column3: He remained moody and indolent, incapable of exertion, and a prey to the darkest humours; circumstances, however, occurred which rendered some energy on his part absolutely necessary. His creditors grew importunate, and the arrangement of his affairs or departure from his native land was an alternative now inevitable.

column2: The month of April, which witnessed the arrival of the Temples and Lord Montfort in England, welcomed also to London Miss Grandison and her guests.
column3: The month of April, which witnessed the arrival of the Temples and Lord Montfort in England, welcomed also to London Miss Grandison and her guests.

column2: A few weeks after, Ferdinand, who had evaded the journey with his family, and who would not on any account become a guest of his cousin, settled himself down at a quiet hotel in the vicinity of Grosvenor-square; but not quite alone, for almost at the last hour Glastonbury had requested permission to accompany him, and Ferdinand, who duly valued the society of the only person with whom he could converse about his broken fortunes and his blighted hopes without reserve, acceded to his wish with the greatest satisfaction.
column3: A few weeks after, Ferdinand, who had evaded the journey with his family, and who would not on any account become a guest of his cousin, settled himself down at a quiet hotel in the vicinity of Grosvenor square; but not quite alone, for almost at the last hour Glastonbury had requested permission to accompany him, and Ferdinand, who duly valued the society of the only person with whom he could converse about his broken fortunes and his blighted hopes without reserve, acceded to his wish with the greatest satisfaction.

column2: A sudden residence in a vast metropolis, after a life of rural seclusion, has without doubt a very peculiar effect upon the mind.
column3: A sudden residence in a vast metropolis, after a life of rural seclusion, has without doubt a very peculiar effect upon the mind.

column2: The immense population, the multiplicity of objects, the important interests hourly impressed upon the intelligence, the continually occurring events, the noise, the bustle, the general and widely-spread excitement, all combine to make us keenly sensible of our individual insignificance; and those absorbing passions that in our solitude, fed by our imagination, have assumed such gigantic and substantial shapes, rapidly subside, by an almost imperceptible process, into less colossal proportions, and seem invested, as it were, with a more shadowy aspect. As Ferdinand Armine jostled his way through the crowded streets of London, urged on by his own harassing and inexorable affairs, and conscious of the impending peril of his career, while power and wealth dazzled his eyes in all directions, he began to look back upon the passionate past with feelings of less keen sensation than heretofore, and almost to regret that a fatal destiny or his impetuous soul had entailed upon him so much anxiety, and prompted him to reject the glittering cup of fortune that had been proffered to him so opportunely. He sighed for enjoyment and repose; the memory of his recent sufferings made him shrink from that reckless indulgence of the passions, of which the consequences had been so severe.
column3: The immense population, the multiplicity of objects, the important interests hourly impressed upon the intelligence, the continually occurring events, the noise, the bustle, the general and widely spread excitement, all combine to make us keenly sensible of our individual insignificance; and those absorbing passions that in our solitude, fed by our imagination, have assumed such gigantic and substantial shapes, rapidly subside, by an almost imperceptible process, into less colossal proportions, and seem invested, as it were, with a more shadowy aspect. As Ferdinand Armine jostled his way through the crowded streets of London, urged on by his own harassing and inexorable affairs, and conscious of the impending peril of his career, while power and wealth dazzled his eyes in all directions, he began to look back upon the passionate past with feelings of less keen sensation than heretofore, and almost to regret that a fatal destiny or his impetuous soul had entailed upon him so much anxiety, and prompted him to reject the glittering cup of fortune that had been proffered to him so opportunely. He sighed for enjoyment and repose; the memory of his recent sufferings made him shrink from that reckless indulgence of the passions, of which the consequences had been so severe.

column2: It was in this mood, exhausted by a visit to his lawyer, that he stepped into a military club and took up a newspaper.
column3: It was in this mood, exhausted by a visit to his lawyer, that he stepped into a military club and took up a newspaper.

column2: Caring little for politics, his eye wandered over, uninterested, its pugnacious leading articles and tedious parliamentary reports; and he was about to throw it down when a paragraph caught his notice which instantly engrossed all his attention.
column3: Caring little for politics, his eye wandered over, uninterested, its pugnacious leading articles and tedious parliamentary reports; and he was about to throw it down when a paragraph caught his notice which instantly engrossed all his attention.

column2: It was in the 'Morning Post' that he thus read:
column3: It was in the 'Morning Post' that he thus read:

column2: 'The Marquis of Montfort, the eldest son of the Duke of------, whose return to England we recently noticed, has resided for several years in Italy.
column3: 'The Marquis of Montfort, the eldest son of the Duke of------, whose return to England we recently noticed, has resided for several years in Italy.

column2: His lordship is considered one of the most accomplished noblemen of the day, and was celebrated at Rome for his patronage of the arts. Lord Montfort will shortly be united to the beautiful Miss Temple, the only daughter of the Right Honourable Pelham Temple.
column3: His lordship is considered one of the most accomplished noblemen of the day, and was celebrated at Rome for his patronage of the arts. Lord Montfort will shortly be united to the beautiful Miss Temple, the only daughter of the Right Honourable Pelham Temple.

column2: Miss Temple is esteemed one of the richest heiresses in England, as she will doubtless inherit the whole of the immense fortune to which her father so unexpectedly acceded.
column3: Miss Temple is esteemed one of the richest heiresses in England, as she will doubtless inherit the whole of the immense fortune to which her father so unexpectedly acceded.

column2: Mr. Temple is a widower, and has no son.
column3: mr Temple is a widower, and has no son.

column2: Mr. Temple was formerly our minister at several of the German Courts, where he was distinguished by his abilities and his hospitality to his travelling countrymen.
column3: mr Temple was formerly our minister at several of the German Courts, where he was distinguished by his abilities and his hospitality to his travelling countrymen.

column2: It is said that the rent-roll of the Yorkshire estates of the late Sir Temple Devereux is not less than 15,000L. per annum.
column3: It is said that the rent roll of the Yorkshire estates of the late Sir Temple Devereux is not less than fifteen thousand L. per annum.

column2: The personal property is also very considerable.
column3: The personal property is also very considerable.

column2: We understand that Mr. Temple has purchased the mansion of the Duke of -----, in Grosvenor-square.
column3: We understand that mr Temple has purchased the mansion of the Duke of -----, in Grosvenor square.

column2: Lord Montfort accompanied Mr. Temple and his amiable daughter to this country.'
column3: Lord Montfort accompanied mr Temple and his amiable daughter to this country.'

column2: What a wild and fiery chaos was the mind of Ferdinand Armine when he read this paragraph.
column3: What a wild and fiery chaos was the mind of Ferdinand Armine when he read this paragraph.

column2: The wonders it revealed succeeded each other with such rapidity that for some time he was deprived of the power of reflection.
column3: The wonders it revealed succeeded each other with such rapidity that for some time he was deprived of the power of reflection.

column2: Henrietta Temple in England!
column3: Henrietta Temple in England!

column2: Henrietta Temple one of the greatest heiresses in the country!
column3: Henrietta Temple one of the greatest heiresses in the country!

column2: Henrietta Temple about to be immediately married to another!
column3: Henrietta Temple about to be immediately married to another!

column2: His Henrietta Temple, the Henrietta Temple whom he adored, and by whom he had been worshipped!
column3: His Henrietta Temple, the Henrietta Temple whom he adored, and by whom he had been worshipped!

column2: The Henrietta Temple whose beautiful lock of hair was at this very moment on his heart!
column3: The Henrietta Temple whose beautiful lock of hair was at this very moment on his heart!

column2: The Henrietta Temple for whom he had forfeited fortune, family, power, almost life!
column3: The Henrietta Temple for whom he had forfeited fortune, family, power, almost life!

column2: O Woman, Woman!
column3: O Woman, Woman!

column2: Put not thy trust in woman!
column3: Put not thy trust in woman!

column2: And yet, could he reproach her?
column3: And yet, could he reproach her?

column2: Did she not believe herself trifled with by him, outraged, deceived, deluded, deserted?
column3: Did she not believe herself trifled with by him, outraged, deceived, deluded, deserted?

column2: And did she, could she love another?
column3: And did she, could she love another?

column2: Was there another to whom she had poured forth her heart as to him, and all that beautiful flow of fascinating and unrivalled emotion?
column3: Was there another to whom she had poured forth her heart as to him, and all that beautiful flow of fascinating and unrivalled emotion?

column2: Was there another to whom she had pledged her pure and passionate soul?
column3: Was there another to whom she had pledged her pure and passionate soul?

column2: Ah, no! he would not, he could not believe it.
column3: Ah, no! he would not, he could not believe it.

column2: Light and false Henrietta could never be.
column3: Light and false Henrietta could never be.

column2: She had been seen, she had been admired, she had been loved: who that saw her would not admire and love? and he was the victim of her pique, perhaps of her despair.
column3: She had been seen, she had been admired, she had been loved: who that saw her would not admire and love? and he was the victim of her pique, perhaps of her despair.

column2: But she was not yet married.
column3: But she was not yet married.

column2: They were, according to these lines, to be soon united.
column3: They were, according to these lines, to be soon united.

column2: It appeared they had travelled together; that thought gave him a pang.
column3: It appeared they had travelled together; that thought gave him a pang.

column2: Could he not see her?
column3: Could he not see her?

column2: Could he not explain all?
column3: Could he not explain all?

column2: Could he not prove that his heart had ever been true and fond?
column3: Could he not prove that his heart had ever been true and fond?

column2: Could he not tell her all that had happened, all that he had suffered, all the madness of his misery; and could she resist that voice whose accents had once been her joy, that glance which had once filled her heart with rapture?
column3: Could he not tell her all that had happened, all that he had suffered, all the madness of his misery; and could she resist that voice whose accents had once been her joy, that glance which had once filled her heart with rapture?

column2: And when she found that Ferdinand, her own Ferdinand, had indeed never deceived her, was worthy of her choice affection, and suffering even at this moment for her sweet sake, what were all the cold-blooded ties in which she had since involved herself?
column3: And when she found that Ferdinand, her own Ferdinand, had indeed never deceived her, was worthy of her choice affection, and suffering even at this moment for her sweet sake, what were all the cold blooded ties in which she had since involved herself?

column2: She was his by an older and more ardent bond.
column3: She was his by an older and more ardent bond.

column2: Should he not claim his right?
column3: Should he not claim his right?

column2: Could she deny it?
column3: Could she deny it?

column2: Claim what?
column3: Claim what?

column2: The hand of an heiress.
column3: The hand of an heiress.

column2: Should it be said that an Armine came crouching for lucre, where he ought to have commanded for love? Never!
column3: Should it be said that an Armine came crouching for lucre, where he ought to have commanded for love? Never!

column2: Whatever she might think, his conduct had been faultless to her. It was not for Henrietta to complain.
column3: Whatever she might think, his conduct had been faultless to her. It was not for Henrietta to complain.

column2: She was not the victim, if one indeed there might chance to be.
column3: She was not the victim, if one indeed there might chance to be.

column2: He had loved her, she had returned his passion; for her sake he had made the greatest of sacrifices, forfeited a splendid inheritance, and a fond and faithful heart.
column3: He had loved her, she had returned his passion; for her sake he had made the greatest of sacrifices, forfeited a splendid inheritance, and a fond and faithful heart.

column2: When he had thought of her before, pining perhaps in some foreign solitude, he had never ceased reproaching himself for his conduct, and had accused himself of deception and cruelty; but now, in this moment of her flush prosperity, 'esteemed one of the richest heiresses in England' (he ground his teeth as he recalled that phrase), and the affianced bride of a great noble (his old companion, Lord Montfort, too; what a strange thing is life!), proud, smiling, and prosperous, while he was alone, with a broken heart and worse than desperate fortunes, and all for her sake, his soul became bitter: he reproached her with want of feeling; he pictured her as void of genuine sensibility; he dilated on her indifference since they had parted; her silence, so strange, now no longer inexplicable; the total want of interest she had exhibited as to his career; he sneered at the lightness of her temperament; he cursed her caprice; he denounced her infernal treachery; in the distorted phantom of his agonised imagination she became to him even an object of hatred.
column3: When he had thought of her before, pining perhaps in some foreign solitude, he had never ceased reproaching himself for his conduct, and had accused himself of deception and cruelty; but now, in this moment of her flush prosperity, 'esteemed one of the richest heiresses in England' (he ground his teeth as he recalled that phrase), and the affianced bride of a great noble (his old companion, Lord Montfort, too; what a strange thing is life!), proud, smiling, and prosperous, while he was alone, with a broken heart and worse than desperate fortunes, and all for her sake, his soul became bitter: he reproached her with want of feeling; he pictured her as void of genuine sensibility; he dilated on her indifference since they had parted; her silence, so strange, now no longer inexplicable; the total want of interest she had exhibited as to his career; he sneered at the lightness of her temperament; he cursed her caprice; he denounced her infernal treachery; in the distorted phantom of his agonised imagination she became to him even an object of hatred.

column2: Poor Ferdinand Armine! it was the first time he had experienced the maddening pangs of jealousy.
column3: Poor Ferdinand Armine! it was the first time he had experienced the maddening pangs of jealousy.

column2: Yet how he had loved this woman!
column3: Yet how he had loved this woman!

column2: How he had doated on her!
column3: How he had doated on her!

column2: And now they might have been so happy!
column3: And now they might have been so happy!

column2: There is nothing that depresses a man so much as the conviction of bad fortune.
column3: There is nothing that depresses a man so much as the conviction of bad fortune.

column2: There seemed, in this sudden return, great wealth, and impending marriage of Henrietta Temple, such a combination, so far as Ferdinand Armine was concerned, of vexatious circumstances; it would appear that he had been so near perfect happiness and missed it, that he felt quite weary of existence, and seriously meditated depriving himself of it.
column3: There seemed, in this sudden return, great wealth, and impending marriage of Henrietta Temple, such a combination, so far as Ferdinand Armine was concerned, of vexatious circumstances; it would appear that he had been so near perfect happiness and missed it, that he felt quite weary of existence, and seriously meditated depriving himself of it.

column2: It so happened that he had promised this day to dine at his cousin's; for Glastonbury, who was usually his companion, had accepted an invitation this day to dine with the noble widow of his old patron. Ferdinand, however, found himself quite incapable of entering into any society, and he hurried to his hotel to send a note of excuse to Brook-street.
column3: It so happened that he had promised this day to dine at his cousin's; for Glastonbury, who was usually his companion, had accepted an invitation this day to dine with the noble widow of his old patron. Ferdinand, however, found himself quite incapable of entering into any society, and he hurried to his hotel to send a note of excuse to Brook street.

column2: As he arrived, Glastonbury was just about to step into a hackney-coach, so that Ferdinand had no opportunity of communicating his sorrows to his friend, even had he been inclined.
column3: As he arrived, Glastonbury was just about to step into a hackney coach, so that Ferdinand had no opportunity of communicating his sorrows to his friend, even had he been inclined.

column2: WHEN Glastonbury arrived at the mansion of the good old duchess, he found nobody in the drawing-room but a young man of distinguished appearance, whose person was unknown to him, but who nevertheless greeted him with remarkable cordiality.
column3: WHEN Glastonbury arrived at the mansion of the good old duchess, he found nobody in the drawing room but a young man of distinguished appearance, whose person was unknown to him, but who nevertheless greeted him with remarkable cordiality.

column2: The good Glastonbury returned, with some confusion, his warm salutation.
column3: The good Glastonbury returned, with some confusion, his warm salutation.
